Situation1: They see a group of teenagers ignoring the no-diving signs near the pool edge.
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They recognize the importance of being present at weekly services regularly
Story: I stood at the edge of the pool, whistle in hand, eyes fixed on a group of teenagers laughing and pushing each other dangerously close to the no-diving signs. As a lifeguard, I knew I had to enforce the rules—no exceptions. My supervisor had made it clear: safety comes first, and letting things slide could cost someone dearly. But as I glanced at my watch, my heart tightened. Sunday service was about to start, and I’d promised my church group I’d be there to help set up. My faith was my anchor, and being present at worship was more than a routine; it was a commitment to my beliefs and my community. The tension inside me grew as the teens edged closer to the water, their laughter echoing. I felt torn, pulled between my duty to protect these kids and my responsibility to honor my faith. The minutes ticked by, and I wrestled with the weight of both roles, knowing I couldn’t fully satisfy the demands of each at this moment.
